video_path: C:\Users\chris\Dropbox\Scripts\clip-video\brands\KCD-UK\videos\Dom Goodwin   Miles Bryant - Payday Pandemonium How Monzo Survives a Daily Self-Inflicted DDoS.mp4
text: Thank you for coming along Hope you're all suitably fed and hydrated and ready to listen to us talk about getting paid but also getting paged So who are we I'm Miles I'm a senior staff engineer in platform at Monzo working on infrastructure platform looking after compute networking observability And I'm Dom I'm a staff engineer inside the same squad Miles just mentioned so all the same stuff And we work at Monzo Who has heard of Monzo I'm glad there are a few Monzo people in the audience who have put their hand up We're a digital bank we have 40 million customers in the UK business retail etc We have a product in the US that's growing and we are just about to start expanding more internationally to the EU which is exciting But one of the fundamental features of a bank is letting you get paid by your employer which is pretty important right And in the UK one of the main ways that this happens is via a payment scheme called BACS which stands for Bankers Automated Clearing System And this powers lots of scheduled payments so it might power things like your gym membership or your utility bill via direct debits but it also works the other way with direct credits which are used for salary payments And this is broadly how BACS works It works on a three day timeline right So on day one your employer is going to run your payroll work out how much you should be paid and send that off to their bank Their bank is then going to send that to BACS and BACS by the next day is going to forward that on to Monzo and say please credit all of these people their salary And then normally what happens on day three all the money sort of moves around it settles gets credited into people's accounts and everyone's happy right But one of the really interesting features of this system is that if someone makes a mistake if their payroll's wrong then the source bank can actually ask BACS to cancel the credit and say please don't pay this person we've made a mistake But the deadline for that is actually at 3 30 p m on day two And past that point we basically know how much everyone's going to be paid so we thought why wait till the next day Why not just give people money then And we built this feature about six years ago or so Pretty nice you open the app you have this lovely little animation you drag it down and you get your money straight away instead of having to wait sort of overnight and wake up the next day And we decided well we know what people are going to be paid at 3 30 p m so let's make it available at 4 p m on the day Can anyone think of any potential issues with inviting all your users to open their app and receive money at the same time every time they get paid Yeah Turns out we found out pretty quickly within the first month of building this that yeah people really like getting paid Doubled our edge traffic We've not scaled up our systems at all and that did not end well And we thought well what are we going to do here right We could roll back this feature You know we could go back and figure out how to build it more safely or whatever But it's a really really good feature People really really like cottoned on to and really like this feature straight away And we wanted to work out how we could sort of That's what we're going to talk to you about today We're going to take you through our journey from payday pandemonium to salary serenity And we're going to dig into lots of different strategies that even if you're not a bank you can use for any sort of load events that you might have But first going to hand over to Dom to talk a bit more about our platform environment Yeah Thank you So we're just going to set some basic background of what our platform looks like so when we're talking about things it's in context So to start with Monzo's architecture this is not a very detailed diagram you'll note But at a high level we run in a single AWS region AWS1 didn't go down the other day We run a EKS cluster and on that EKS cluster is a range of workloads from our microservices There's about 3 000 or so and counting We've got our observability stack So that's profiling tracing monitoring metrics and logging We then have Kafka clusters We run three main Kafka clusters that sort of power the bank and the various systems that go there And then we've got other components around the This is everything you'd expect for a working Kubernetes cluster from low balancer controllers to metrics exporters to everything We then have a range of AWS services we use as well We don't use too many of these but we have S3 for our blob storage We've got keyspaces for managed Cassandra We actually give each microservice its own keyspace if it wants it And then we also run etcd clusters on EC2 nodes outside the cluster We've got about six or seven of these clusters currently running Jumping into Kubernetes specifically is KCD We have a set of node pools that Carpenter is managing We have some that are both spot and on demand for our microservices as a whole We actually run like 90  spot nodes and various other components that run on them as well I actually gave a talk last year more details about Carpenter if you want to hear that Just a self plug We then have on demand node pools as well to run things that don't handle spot terminations If you've got two minutes notice you don't want your metrics ingestion or your Kafka clusters to be killed very quickly so they run separately on node pools that have slow drift and management there We then also expose pods directly using low balancers So we've got NLBs and ALBs exposing the pods So when you hit the end points in the app you're hitting low balancers which is just hitting pods on our edge and then that goes into all the microservice traffic from there One layer deeper then we've got microservices Now microservices are a contentious topic sometimes and I think people a lot of the time picture 10 different languages 10 different database stacks and all sorts of things powering the microservices We have a single database that we use which is Cassandra We write 95  of these microservices in Go and all the interactions with third party and common components is done by our Us in the platform team write and manage these libraries so if someone talks to Cassandra and someone talks to Kafka it goes via abstracted libraries first then we can actually control and manage that at a platform level We then have Envoy deployed as well for our service mesh so all service communication goes via these Envoy MTLS connections and that's running a mesh that we write and manage ourselves So back to getPaidEarly now The question really is why is getPaidEarly so bad and why do we have these problematic DDoS events that form So when people get paid you get peaks throughout the month If everyone who here gets paid in the last five days of the month or so nice we have hands up That's more than a sixth of the thing People get paid normally at the end or the start of the month and that doesn't distribute evenly throughout the month What this means is all the paydays will group up together and then because of the back system where it's only on business days they'll group up even more If your payday lands on a weekend then you'll get paid on the Friday instead Lastly we have bank holidays which then also cause more grouping up Bank holidays are pretty much always Mondays or Fridays so it causes further people's paydays to get together This is more notable with things like the August bank holiday for example that's at the end of August and then we've also got like bank holidays in Easter that move around as well all the time so the Easter bank holiday next year is actually forming at the end of March so we have a six or seven day payday all at one happening at once If there's an incident then I'm on holiday It's not me Now the other thing about getPaidEarly that makes this worse is 4pm is the time when most people in the UK are awake They're not asleep which is what normally happens when you get paid If you have a payday and you get paid whatever time happens in the morning when the back run goes through you don't wake up to get paid You will wake up gradually throughout the morning as your alarm goes off and maybe do a bit of banking when you wake up as that money comes in This is actually our edge proxy graph showing the amount of traffic that we get during the morning You can actually see people's do not disturb and alarms going off so every half an hour you get these peaks This is quite nice because if you're a horizontal pod office scaler you can scale for this quite easily You're not getting these massive surges that are suddenly happening and as people wake up they do more banking stuff and we can slowly gradually ramp up and scale out our platform throughout the day And here's what happens at 4pm This is a graph of our edge proxy traffic showing the amount of requests a second we get This was from about two months ago when quite a lot of getPaidEarly and you can see our edge requests went from about 20 000 a second to nearly 50 000 This spike actually looks a bit better than it normally is This spike is in the space of a minute as well so the amount of traffic hitting services in a minute is rocketing up Now this isn't actually traffic driven by us This is just customers going it's 4pm I'm meant to get paid I'm going to open my Monza app and try and get paid As you can expect this causes a lot of problems particularly back in 2019 when we had no auto scaling whatsoever The other edge of this is we get say 20 000 extra requests a second on our edge What that actually translates to across our microservices and our service mesh is about 10 million requests a second for all the services If you think a single API call to load your feed might actually be 300 sources of information and RPC calls that gets made so you can see how the amount of traffic that ramps up in the space of a minute really hits our platform Now what happens when this goes wrong Well we have a set of cascading failures that occur and I'm just going to talk through sort of a single service example here This graph is showing the amount of memory a service uses when it gets overwhelmed The red line is showing memory spiking up and then the red dotted lines are annotations when they have out of memory kills This isn't actually too bad We have a few pods that are crashing and overall we can handle the amount of retries we need to basically avoid it causing too much of a This is the amount of requests coming in and the error rate for those requests and you can see that we actually only got about five requests erroring a second during these out of memory kills This looks fine The problem is what happens upstream Now a pod talking to another pod has connections and we use longstanding HTTP2 connections That's because MTS connections are expensive to initiate so we basically reuse those to avoid having latency when we're setting up those new connections When the pod goes down we have to set up a lot more of those connections and we have to have retries in the service mesh so the cascading failure of a single service actually means that all the upstreams have increased latency increased memory usage and they can also fail causing even further cascading across our microservices So how do we fix this How do we prevent services from being overwhelmed from sudden spikes of Well back to Miles So clearly we have a problem here right We have too much demand with too many requests per second and we don't have enough supply of service CPU cycles or memory to service it So what do we do Well in the beginning as Don mentioned we didn't have horizontal autoscaling We just had statically set scale per service So the very first thing was obviously to scale things up and we did this initially just manually reactively in the instant We go okay which services are crashing which are under lots of load just write this list and then go through them one by one and scale No magic or fancy automation Let's do it And then we decided to be a bit more proactive about it and start reusing the same list scaling up the same services but we wanted to get a bit more confidence that we were scaling the right services and when we came to the next get paid early things would actually work And to do this we did load testing to kind of simulate what might happen during a get paid early I think load testing can be quite tricky with a complex product like Monzo It's not just a single API endpoint that you can just point an off the shelf tool at and just ramp up the number of requests When you open your app as a Monzo user and load the feed there are tens or hundreds of API endpoints the app is going to be calling to actually fetch that information and display it So we really wanted to try and simulate as faithfully the journey of a user opening the app at get paid early So we wrote our own load test worker for this that kind of ran through that journey and hit these endpoints and we built our own simple orchestrator that could spin up lots of these workers and hammer our API We could do our scaling and see whether it actually worked and adjust from there Now this was fine for a while right You know while we were getting started but we quickly ran into some of the problems with this approach So the first issue is that Monzo is a moving target right Constantly developing new features new products like a few weeks past and there are more products and services that are on the app load hot path And it only takes one of those services to appear that we haven't got on our scaling list and suddenly you know no matter how much load testing we do the next get paid early that service might fall over and cause a cascading failure This process also took so much time right We were probably spending up to about two three hours a week just scaling and load testing and doing all of this and it's not particularly glamorous work but it's also like time we can't spend on actually building features and improving Monzo And also like doing things manually as we all know people make mistakes and yeah we decided to make it better So one of the first things we thought of doing is actually Kubernetes has a built in tool for scaler which does what it says on the tin You give it some input and it adjusts the number of pods for you Now in our case we figured that our main constraint is CPU We receive lots of HTTP requests The services have to do CPU work to service those requests and so more requests we need more CPU So we targeted about 70  CPU utilization And HPA works well for reacting it's pretty fast it can spin up a bunch of pods in under 30 seconds but it still takes time for Kubernetes to actually spin up those pods So we needed something else In particular if we try and add you know 100 or 200 pods to our cluster and our cluster doesn't actually have the capacity to like schedule those pods straight away then yeah we have to wait for those new nodes to come up and that can take a bit of time Even like we're using Boterocket and EKS find it spins up really really quickly but it still might not be quick enough So one thing we did was to reserve space in the kind of proactively And the solution we found for this was just to run a simple deployment that just runs the Kubernetes force container just runs idle all the time We can reserve the resources and they can just sit in the cluster taking up space But the key bit is that we use the priority class feature of Kubernetes too We can set the priority really really low and then whenever an actual real service pod that we want to schedule comes along Kubernetes can actually evict these from the node schedule the real pod and like spin it up really really quickly It allows us to keep lots and lots of headroom around And the other thing as I said is we started doing more proactive scaling and starting to scale services up before 4pm because obviously we know exactly when this load spike is going to happen We're quite privileged in that respect And this allows us to just make sure we've got supply of service CPU cycles when that hits And yeah we started off doing it then we moved to automating it and building a system that would generate a plan for the services we needed to scale and then actually run through the plan and scale up each service individually before 4pm And needed to do a few checks while doing this to make sure we didn't deploy things normally to the cluster but even so doing it slightly slowly we can scale these whole thing in less than an hour But the really interesting part of the system is actually how do we know how much to scale services up by Like I said people are adding new services and new endpoints and things all of the time which are just constantly going into this app load hot path that we care about so much And one of the things that we found really really worked for us was using our tracing data using Jaeger and Otel And this actually allowed us to look at the endpoints that are on the app load hot path get a list of all of the services that were being called by that and say okay we know we need to this is the list of services that we actually need to We could also use some other inputs like previous get paid early peaks and metrics from services we could compare how much CPU each service had how much we had to the HPA had to scale up the service by and use that to inform the plan for the future And the other important thing of this was of course scaling back down afterwards we didn't want to just leave our system scaled up all of the time cost money waste resources And we found for this we could just reverse the process and drop the number of minimum replicas in the HPA And then the system would sort of naturally scale down over time as like the user load sort of tapered off into the evening And then we find our cluster board scaler just scaled in the So that's Dom to talk about shedding load So we've talked now about how we can scale up things to handle the big spike of traffic coming in But what about what we can do to actually just reduce the spike of traffic itself load shedding at Monzo had quite small beginnings We basically had some people during incidents who were like here's a useful thing I did last time that avoided some load And it was just grown fully out of incidents We'd have incidents we'd type in the channel oh you know we think we should just turn this thing off and someone has the expertise to know it's not going to break everything And we basically had this set of tools that we could use to reduce the load on our platform Over time obviously word of mouth incident relying on a single person to be in an incident who knows what to do isn't ideal So we sort of built this into a set of runbooks We've had quite a few incidents at this point So this runbook went to about 40 different load shedders that we could have These were all written down with a set of manual steps of how to operate them whether it be turning off config or scaling down something But these all were written in a way that we knew it wasn't going to impact customers We could scale turn this thing off and it's not going to actually change the customer experience in the app which was the key thing here We also rated what the load shedders were by the level of customer impact they'd have So you'd know if it was going to have no customer impact or major customer impact Major still being better than you know the entire bank goes down Which doesn't happen Then to talk through some of the load shedders yeah To talk through some of the load shedders we had a key one is disabling unimportant background asynchronous tasks As you can imagine think through your own environments there is a lot of things that run in the background that don't need to be done in real time One thing notably for us is our analytics pipeline We don't need analytics events to be shipped the second they're produced So we can allow them to back up on a queue They're just going to wait there on Kafka and then we can process them later We do quite like them to be recent So we do actually process in near real time constantly But when we have large get paid early peaks we can basically rate limit the processing of those reduce the amount of traffic that those analytics event processing and enrichments are causing and we can reduce the load on our platform to sort of lighten the load and make sure we're not going to be overwhelmed There's other background tasks as well that don't have to be processed in real time like our batch iteration jobs and master card clearing These basically just mean that we can you know hold off processing in the ten minute peak that get paid early is going to hit The other side of this is we can actually cache information Now as a bank we don't really want to overuse caching because the whole benefit of Monzo is you see up to date real time information You spend five pounds at the pub and then you see that money go out of your app right away If we were caching that and we were like oh we're not going to tell you for an hour that wouldn't really be an ideal user experience So we want to use caching sparingly We found however that some endpoints could be cached without having any customer impact or very minor customer impact These are ones where when you get a push notification to your phone we preload information in the background for you The idea being we can have some information loaded in the app so the app loads quicker when you open it up Instead of having this data load we just cache the data from the push notifications and this meant we could actually reduce traffic from those by about 5 This graph is actually showing the amount of traffic we were caching during a recent get paid early and it's all of the non green lines You can basically see that about 5 to 10  of our traffic we could cache without anyone knowing we're caching it and we could all that load hitting our downstream systems This gets turned on during most large get paid earlies and we basically have thresholds for how large those are and if we're going to turn them on or not What we found over time however with our load shedding runbooks is manual processes aren't great because they rely on humans that have to run them and humans can make mistakes and forget to run them or forget to turn them off sometimes So instead we built another microservice to run the load shedding for the rest of the microservices This service is called the load shedder and it sheds load It basically is the runbook and it's just automating all those steps in the runbook that we know have worked and have been tried and tested in an instance before You can easily call this load shedder just making an RPC request in the CLI to say enable this set of load shedding and anyone at Monzo can run these and anyone can do them easily The idea being that anyone responding to an instance doesn't need to page platform they can just say oh platform's being overwhelmed by load let's start shedding no custom impact load here Again these have the levels of customer impact as well Someone just knows if I enable level 3 customers might notice If I enable level 0 no one's going to know it's actually on Lastly we thought how can we actually change get paid early the As we mentioned we don't want to just say in platform no you can't have get paid early as a feature Customers love it You know so many so many percentages of customers actually get paid early each week If we turned it off people wouldn't be happy and we don't want to have to have platform deriving the features that we can offer So instead we can actually change what get paid early does to make it just a bit lighter on platform The first get paid early what happened is at 4 p m on the dot we sent everyone a notification if they were eligible saying come get paid As you can imagine not just everyone coming to the app at 4 p m but telling people to come to the app and sending them a notification causes lots of load on the platform and causes lots of issues Now you can see this graph on the right showing we actually send out notifications half an hour later and we send them out over an hour period so we're not overwhelming our platform at once The funny thing with this is customers want to get paid at 4 p m on the dot still so even without a notification they're still opening the app at 4 p m This weight limiting has been in place for years now and we still have an edge proxy graph that triples when get paid early hits but I imagine it would be worse if we hadn't have done this The other thing we can do is delay processing of get paid early payments so you might have seen on some very large get paid early this message in your app that says your money is coming soon this is only like a one to two minute wait but by rate limiting the amount of payments we process we can reduce the load on downstream systems and control it so it's not just driven by customer behavior but we also have platform levers we can control to lower the rate of payments as well which is very useful So back to Myles what's next So our journey has been pretty successful Like you know five six years ago the really big get paid early peaks were always a terrifying kind of see in the morning the size of the peak and then go right what are we going to do Let's go and shed a load of load and scale things Whereas now they're pretty much non events Like they just happen all the time We don't know It basically works So what do we want to do next here One thing is on our current scaling system It works fine It's basically a bunch of code with heuristics which is quite challenging actually to iterate on and like if we want to make improvements if we want to change how it scales it's quite tricky But really this is a sort of data and ML shape problem we have a bunch of inputs we have you know previous service scaling data get paid early size et cetera et cetera We should be able to train and iterate on a model offline that produces nice scaling plans And this is one way that we could make scaling more efficient and cost effective over time We also want to look at the scaling part of the system itself And instead of having our kind of hand rolled services that interact directly with the horizontal portal to scaler with maybe a custom proactive like scaling signal from our plan generation and just have one system doing all of the scaling And yeah to wrap up a few takeaways So first thing is minor product decisions can have very outsized long term impact on user behavior Like it seems really really obvious to see that now that like you know we let people get paid at 4 p m everyone's going to want to get paid at 4 p m It wasn't necessarily so obvious at the time right We didn't know how popular this feature was going to be We've also spoken about a bunch of strategies reactive auto scaling proactive auto scaling load shedding et cetera et cetera And I think one of the more general takeaways as well is that you don't necessarily need to kind of solve the world up front and try and magically automate everything You know it's fine to just start manual with a few kind of small steps and then build on that as the as you see that success and wins from doing those small steps start automating things and move on to the next thing I think finally one of the most important things that's really helped us through this journey is making sure we use our instance as like a primary learning opportunity for improving our system Like instance happen they are expensive lessons you know it makes sense to get the most out of them as you can kind of run postmortems and debriefs and take actions and come up with ideas And that's it There's a couple of blog posts we've referenced We'll leave the links up there But otherwise thank you so much and enjoy the rest of your day Bye
